newsitem.title: USA: Missouri soy sowing advances, wheat harvest starts.
newsitem.headline: Missouri soy sowing advances, wheat harvest starts.

text.p: Soybean planting in Missouri during the week ended Sunday was 11 days ahead of last year's pace and eight days ahead of the five-year average, according to the state's agricultural statistics service weekly report.
Single-crop soybeans were 87 percent planted with more than 90 percent planted in the northwest, north central and central districts.
Corn continued to develop and crop conditions were largely unchanged from the previous week at six percent excellent, 51 percent good, 37 fair, five percent poor and one very poor.
Cool weather and a lack of sunshine has slowed growth.
Sorghum was 86 percent planted, five days ahead of 1996 and six days ahead of the five-year average of 76 percent.

Three percent of the cotton was squaring, about eight days ahead of last year but six days behind the five-year average of 12 percent. Crop condition declined slightly from a week ago with 30 percent rated good, 37 fair, 31 poor and two percent very poor. The crop needed sun and warm weather to promote growth.

Winter wheat condition was near unchanged with 62 percent rated good to excellent, 27 fair, 10 poor and one very poor. About 66 percent of the crop had turned color, ahead of 58 percent a year ago but the same as the average. One percent was harvested versus two percent last year and the four average.
Topsoil moisture was rated 18 percent surplus, 67 adequate and 15 short.
Pasture and ranges were rated five percent excellent, 54 good, 32 fair, eight poor and one very poor.
